defs.docs: Asynchronous DNS resolving.

attributes.value: ! Asynchronous DNS resolving.
! In the DNS, a resolver processes and attempts to answer questions. This
! crate provides a number of such resolvers â€“ or will be, once it is more
! complete. In addition, the crate provides higher level abstraction of
! the information that can be obtained via DNS queries. We call these
! _lookups_.
! The various types of resolvers available all implement the [`Resolver`]
! trait which provides the basic functionality of all resolvers:
! asynchronously answering questions.
! The following resolvers are available:
! *  [`StubResolver`] is the most simple resolver of them all. It is being
!    configured with a list of upstream resolvers and simply forwards all
!    queries to those resolvers, expecting them to do all the heavy work.
!    See the [stub] module for more information on how to use the stub
!    resolver.
! The lookups implemented by the crate are generic over the particular
! resolver, so you can pick the resolver most suitable for your own
! application or even implement your own specialised resolver. All
! lookups are implemented as functions in the [lookup] module. For
! convenience, they are also available as methods on the [`Resolver`]
! trait.
! [lookup]: lookup/index.html
! [stub]: stub/index.html
! [`Resolver`]: resolver/trait.Resolver.html
! [`StubResolver`]: stub/struct.StubResolver.html

defs.name: lookup
defs.docs: Lookup functions and related types.

attributes.value: ! Lookup functions and related types.
! This module collects a number of more or less complex lookups that
! implement applications of the DNS.

defs.docs: Looking up host names for addresses.

attributes.value: ! Looking up host names for addresses.

defs.name: lookup_addr
defs.docs: Resolves the host names of an IP address.

attributes.value: / Resolves the host names of an IP address.
/ The function will query DNS using the resolver represented by `resolv`.
/ It will query DNS only and not consider any other database the system
/ may have.
/ The value returned upon success can be turned into an iterator over
/ host names via its `iter()` method. This is due to lifetime issues.

defs.name: FoundAddrs
defs.docs: The success type of the `lookup_addr()` function.

attributes.value: / The success type of the `lookup_addr()` function.
/ The only purpose of this type is to return an iterator over host names
/ via its `iter()` method.

defs.name: iter
defs.docs: Returns an iterator over the host names.

attributes.value: / Returns an iterator over the host names.

defs.name: FoundAddrsIter
defs.docs: An iterator over host names returned by address lookup.

attributes.value: / An iterator over host names returned by address lookup.

defs.name: host
defs.docs: Looking up host names.

attributes.value: ! Looking up host names.

defs.name: lookup_host
defs.value: fn <R> (resolver: &R, qname: impl ToDname) -> Result<FoundHosts<R>, io::Error>
defs.docs: Creates a future that resolves a host name into its IP addresses.

attributes.value: / Creates a future that resolves a host name into its IP addresses.
/ The future will use the resolver given in `resolv` to query the
/ DNS for the IPv4 and IPv6 addresses associated with `name`.
/ The value returned upon success can be turned into an iterator over
/ IP addresses or even socket addresses. Since the lookup may determine that
/ the host name is in fact an alias for another name, the value will also
/ return the canonical name.

defs.name: search_host
defs.value: fn <R> (resolver: &R, qname: impl ToRelativeDname) -> Result<FoundHosts<R>, io::Error>

defs.name: FoundHosts
defs.docs: The value returned by a successful host lookup.

attributes.value: / The value returned by a successful host lookup.
/ You can use the `iter()` method to get an iterator over the IP addresses
/ or `port_iter()` to get an iterator over socket addresses with the given
/ port.
/ The `canonical_name()` method returns the canonical name of the host for
/ which the addresses were found.

defs.name: new
defs.value: fn (aaaa: Result<R::Answer, io::Error>, a: Result<R::Answer, io::Error>) -> Result<Self, io::Error>

defs.docs: Returns a reference to the canonical name for the host.

attributes.value: / Returns a reference to the canonical name for the host.

defs.name: iter
defs.docs: Returns an iterator over the IP addresses returned by the lookup.

attributes.value: / Returns an iterator over the IP addresses returned by the lookup.

defs.name: port_iter
defs.docs: Returns an iterator over socket addresses gained from the lookup.

attributes.value: / Returns an iterator over socket addresses gained from the lookup.
/ The socket addresses are gained by combining the IP addresses with
/ `port`. The returned iterator implements `ToSocketAddrs` and thus
/ can be used where `std::net` wants addresses right away.

defs.docs: An iterator over the IP addresses returned by a host lookup.

attributes.value: / An iterator over the IP addresses returned by a host lookup.

defs.name: FoundHostsSocketIter
defs.docs: An iterator over socket addresses derived from a host lookup.

attributes.value: / An iterator over socket addresses derived from a host lookup.

defs.name: srv
defs.docs: Looking up SRV records.

attributes.value: ! Looking up SRV records.

defs.name: lookup_srv
defs.value: fn (resolver: &impl Resolver, service: impl ToRelativeDname, name: impl ToDname, fallback_port: u16) -> Result<Option<FoundSrvs>, SrvError>
defs.docs: Creates a future that looks up SRV records.

attributes.value: / Creates a future that looks up SRV records.
/ The future will use the resolver given in `resolver` to query the
/ DNS for SRV records associated with domain name `name` and service
/ `service`.
/ The value returned upon success can be turned into a stream of
/ `ResolvedSrvItem`s corresponding to the found SRV records, ordered as per
/ the usage rules defined in [RFC 2782]. If no matching SRV record is found,
/ A/AAAA queries on the bare domain name `name` will be attempted, yielding
/ a single element upon success using the port given by `fallback_port`,
/ typcially the standard port for the service in question.
/ Each item in the stream can be turned into an iterator over socket
/ addresses as accepted by, for instance, `TcpStream::connect`.
/ The future resolves to `None` whenever the request service is
/ â€œdecidedly not availableâ€ at the requested domain, that is there is a
/ single SRV record with the root label as its target.

defs.name: into_stream
defs.value: fn <'r, R> (self, resolver: &'r R) -> impl Stream<Item = Result<ResolvedSrvItem, io::Error>> + 'r

defs.name: merge
defs.docs: Moves all results from `other` into `Self`, leaving `other` empty.

attributes.value: / Moves all results from `other` into `Self`, leaving `other` empty.
/ Reorders merged results as if they were from a single query.

defs.name: resolver
defs.docs: The trait defining an abstract resolver.

attributes.value: ! The trait defining an abstract resolver.

defs.name: Resolver
defs.docs: A type that acts as a DNS resolver.

attributes.value: / A type that acts as a DNS resolver.
/ A resolver is anything that tries to answer questions using the DNS. The
/ `query` method takes a single question and returns a future that will
/ eventually resolve into either an answer or an IO error.

defs.name: Answer
defs.docs: The answer returned by a query.

attributes.value: / The answer returned by a query.
/ This isnâ€™t `Message` directly as it may be useful for the resolver
/ to provide additional information. For instance, a validating
/ resolver (a resolver that checks whether DNSSEC signatures are
/ correct) can supply more information as to why validation failed.

defs.name: Query
defs.docs: The future resolving into an answer.

attributes.value: / The future resolving into an answer.

defs.name: query
defs.docs: Returns a future answering a question.

attributes.value: / Returns a future answering a question.
/ The method takes anything that can be converted into a question and
/ produces a future trying to answer the question.

defs.name: SearchNames
defs.docs: A type that can produce a list of name suffixes.

attributes.value: / A type that can produce a list of name suffixes.
/ Legacy systems have the ability to interpret relative domain names as
/ within the local system. They provide a list of suffixes that can be
/ attached to the name to make it absolute.
/ A search resolver is a resolver that provides such a list. This is
/ implemented via an iterator over domain names.

defs.name: search_iter
defs.docs: Returns an iterator over the search suffixes.

attributes.value: / Returns an iterator over the search suffixes.

defs.name: conf
defs.docs: Resolver configuration

attributes.value: ! Resolver configuration
! There are two parts to this module: Query options that allow you to
! modify the behaviour of the resolver on a query by query basis and
! the global resolver configuration (normally read from the systemâ€™s
! `/etc/resolv.conf`) that contains things like the name servers to query
! and a set of default options.
! Both parts are modeled along the lines of glibcâ€™s resolver.

defs.name: ResolvOptions
defs.value: ResolvOptions { search, ndots, timeout, attempts, aa_only, use_vc, primary, ign_tc, recurse, default_names, stay_open, dn_search, use_inet6, rotate, no_check_name, keep_tsig, blast, use_bstring, use_ip6dotint, use_edns0, single_request, single_request_reopen, no_tld_query }
defs.docs: Options for the resolver configuration.

attributes.value: / Options for the resolver configuration.
/ This type contains a lot of options that influence the resolver
/ configuration. It collects all server-indpendent options that glibcâ€™s
/ resolver supports. Not all of them are currently supported by this
/ implementation.

defs.name: search
defs.docs: Search list for host-name lookup.

attributes.value: / Search list for host-name lookup.

 Number of dots before an initial absolute query is made.

defs.name: timeout
defs.docs: Timeout to wait for a response.

attributes.value: / Timeout to wait for a response.

defs.name: attempts
defs.docs: Number of retries before giving up.

attributes.value: / Number of retries before giving up.

defs.name: aa_only
defs.docs: Accept authoritative answers only.

attributes.value: / Accept authoritative answers only.
/ Only responses with the AA bit set will be considered. If there
/ arenâ€™t any, the query will fail.
/ This option is not currently implemented. It is likely to be
/ eventually implemented by the query.

defs.name: use_vc
defs.docs: Always use TCP.

attributes.value: / Always use TCP.
/ This option is implemented by the query.

defs.name: primary
defs.docs: Query primary name servers only.

attributes.value: / Query primary name servers only.
/ This option is not currently implemented. It is unclear what exactly
/ it is supposed to mean.

defs.name: ign_tc
defs.docs: Ignore trunactions errors, donâ€™t retry with TCP.

attributes.value: / Ignore trunactions errors, donâ€™t retry with TCP.
/ This option is implemented by the query.

defs.name: recurse
defs.docs: Set the recursion desired bit in queries.

attributes.value: / Set the recursion desired bit in queries.
/ Enabled by default.
/ Implemented by the query request.

defs.name: default_names
defs.docs: Append the default domain name to single component names.

attributes.value: / Append the default domain name to single component names.
/ Enabled by default.
/ This is not currently implemented. Instead, the resolver configâ€™s
/ `search` and `ndots` fields govern resolution of relative names of
/ all kinds.

defs.name: stay_open
defs.docs: Keep TCP connections open between queries.

attributes.value: / Keep TCP connections open between queries.
/ This is not currently implemented.

defs.name: dn_search
defs.docs: Search hostnames in the current domain and parent domains.

attributes.value: / Search hostnames in the current domain and parent domains.
/ Enabled by default.
/ This options is not currently implemented. Instead, the resolver
/ configâ€™s `search` and `ndots` fields govern resolution of relative
/ names.

defs.name: use_inet6
defs.docs: Try AAAA query before A query and map IPv4 responses to tunnel form.

attributes.value: / Try AAAA query before A query and map IPv4 responses to tunnel form.
/ This option is not currently implemented. It is only relevant for
/ `lookup_host`.

defs.name: rotate
defs.docs: Use round-robin selection of name servers.

attributes.value: / Use round-robin selection of name servers.
/ This option is implemented by the query.

defs.name: no_check_name
defs.docs: Disable checking of incoming hostname and mail names.

attributes.value: / Disable checking of incoming hostname and mail names.
/ This is not currently implemented. Or rather, this is currently
/ always onâ€”there is no name checking as yet.

defs.name: keep_tsig
defs.docs: Do not strip TSIG records.

attributes.value: / Do not strip TSIG records.
/ This is not currently implemented. Or rather, no records are stripped
/ at all.

defs.name: blast
defs.docs: Send each query simultaneously to all name servers.

attributes.value: / Send each query simultaneously to all name servers.
/ This is not currently implemented. It would be a query option.

defs.name: use_bstring
defs.docs: Use bit-label format for IPv6 reverse lookups.

attributes.value: / Use bit-label format for IPv6 reverse lookups.
/ Bit labels have been deprecated and consequently, this option is not
/ implemented.

defs.name: use_ip6dotint
defs.docs: Use ip6.int instead of the recommended ip6.arpa.

attributes.value: / Use ip6.int instead of the recommended ip6.arpa.
/ (This option is the reverse of glibcâ€™s `RES_NOIP6DOTINT` option).
/ This option is only relevant for `lookup_addr()` and is implemented
/ there already.

defs.name: use_edns0
defs.docs: Use EDNS0.

attributes.value: / Use EDNS0.
/ EDNS is not yet supported.

defs.name: single_request
defs.docs: Perform IPv4 and IPv6 lookups sequentially instead of in parallel.

attributes.value: / Perform IPv4 and IPv6 lookups sequentially instead of in parallel.
/ This is not yet implemented but would be an option for
/ `lookup_host()`.

defs.name: single_request_reopen
defs.docs: Open a new socket for each request.

attributes.value: / Open a new socket for each request.
/ This is not currently implemented.

defs.name: no_tld_query
defs.docs: Donâ€™t look up unqualified names as top-level-domain.

attributes.value: / Donâ€™t look up unqualified names as top-level-domain.
/ This is not currently implemented. Instead, the resolver configâ€™s
/ `search` and `ndots` fields govern resolution of relative names of
/ all kinds.

defs.name: is_preferred
defs.docs: Returns whether the transport is a preferred transport.

attributes.value: / Returns whether the transport is a preferred transport.
/ Only preferred transports are considered initially. Only if a
/ truncated answer comes back will we consider streaming protocols
/ instead.

defs.docs: Returns whether the transport is a streaming protocol.

attributes.value: / Returns whether the transport is a streaming protocol.

defs.name: ServerConf
defs.value: ServerConf { addr, transport, request_timeout, recv_size, udp_payload_size }
defs.docs: Configuration for one upstream DNS server.

attributes.value: / Configuration for one upstream DNS server.
/ The server is identified by a socket address, ie., an address/port pair.
/ For each server you can set how it should operate on all supported
/ transport protocols, including not at all, and two timeouts for each
/ request and sockets. The timeouts are used for all transports. If you
/ need different timeouts for, say, UDP and TCP, you can always use two
/ server entries with the same address.

defs.name: addr
defs.docs: Server address.

attributes.value: / Server address.

defs.name: transport
defs.docs: Transport protocol.

attributes.value: / Transport protocol.

defs.name: request_timeout
defs.docs: How long to wait for a response before returning a timeout error.

attributes.value: / How long to wait for a response before returning a timeout error.
/ This field defaults to 2 seconds.

defs.name: recv_size
defs.docs: Size of the message receive buffer in bytes.

attributes.value: / Size of the message receive buffer in bytes.
/ This is used for datagram transports only. It defaults to 1232 bytes
/ for both IPv6 and IPv4.
/ (Note: While 1372 bytes works for IPv4 in most scenarios, there has
/ been [research] indicating that sometimes 1232 bytes is the limit here,
/ sometimes too.)
/ [research]: https://rp.delaat.net/2019-2020/p78/report.pdf

defs.name: udp_payload_size
defs.docs: Advertised UDP payload size.

attributes.value: / Advertised UDP payload size.
/ This values will be announced in request if EDNS is supported by the
/ server. It will be included both for datagram and streaming transport
/ but really only matters for UDP.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Returns a new default server config for a given address and transport.

attributes.value: / Returns a new default server config for a given address and transport.
/ The function sets default values as described in the field
/ descriptions above.

defs.name: ResolvConf
defs.docs: Resolver configuration.

attributes.value: / Resolver configuration.
/ This type collects all information necessary to configure how a stub
/ resolver talks to its upstream resolvers.
/ The type follows the builder pattern. After creating a value with
/ `ResolvConf::new()` you can manipulate the members. Once you are happy
/ with them, you call `finalize()` to make sure the configuration is valid.
/ It mostly just fixes the `servers`.
/ Additionally, the type can parse a glibc-style configuration file,
/ commonly known as `/etc/resolv.conf` through the `parse()` and
/ `parse_file()` methods. You still need to call `finalize()` after
/ parsing.
/ The easiest way, however, to get the system resolver configuration is
/ through `ResolvConf::default()`. This will parse the configuration file
/ or return a default configuration if that fails.

defs.name: servers
defs.docs: Addresses of servers to query.

attributes.value: / Addresses of servers to query.

defs.name: options
defs.docs: Default options.

attributes.value: / Default options.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new, empty configuration.

attributes.value: / Creates a new, empty configuration.
/ Using an empty configuration will fail since it does not contain
/ any name servers. Call `self.finalize()` to make it usable.

defs.name: finalize
defs.docs: Finalizes the configuration for actual use.

attributes.value: / Finalizes the configuration for actual use.
/ The function does two things. If `servers` is empty, it adds
/ `127.0.0.1:53`. This is exactly what glibc does. If `search` is
/ empty, it adds the root domain `"."`. This differs from what
/ glibc does which considers the machineâ€™s host name.

defs.name: default
defs.docs: Creates a default configuration for this system.

attributes.value: / Creates a default configuration for this system.
/ XXX This currently only works for Unix-y systems.

defs.name: StubResolver
defs.docs: A DNS stub resolver.

attributes.value: / A DNS stub resolver.
/ This type collects all information making it possible to start DNS
/ queries. You can create a new resoler using the systemâ€™s configuration
/ using the [`new()`] associate function or using your own configuration
/ with [`from_conf()`].
/ Stub resolver values can be cloned relatively cheaply as they keep all
/ information behind an arc.
/ If you want to run a single query or lookup on a resolver synchronously,
/ you can do so simply by using the [`run()`] or [`run_with_conf()`]
/ associated functions.
/ [`new()`]: #method.new
/ [`from_conf()`]: #method.from_conf
/ [`query()`]: #method.query
/ [`run()`]: #method.run
/ [`run_with_conf()`]: #method.run_with_conf
